document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic review of the genus Leucopholis Dejean, 1833 (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Melolonthinae: Leucopholini) in the Philippines

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic review of the genus Leucopholis Dejean, 1833 (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Melolonthinae: Leucopholini) in the Philippines

figureCitation.captionText-0: FIGURE 36 – 40. Leucopholis pulverulenta Burmeister. 36, habitus, dorsal aspect; 37, elytra; 38, male genitalia, dorsal aspect; 39, male genitalia, ventral aspect; 40, male genitalia, lateral aspect.
figureCitation.captionText-1: FIGURE 41. Geographical distribution map of Leucopholis irrorata Chevrolat and Leucopholis pulverulenta Burmeister in the Philippines.
figureCitation.captionText-2: FIGURE 42 – 43. Leucopholis pulverulenta Burmeister. 42, habitus, dorsal aspect (photograph of a non-type from MLU, courtesy of Dr. Karla Schneider); 43, habitus, dorsal aspect (photograph of a non-type from ZMHB, courtesy of Dr. Joachim Willers).

subSubSection.paragraph: Description . Male: length 23.5–29.5 mm , width 11.5–15.5 mm ; female: length 26.0– 32.3 mm , width 13.3–16.5 mm . Frons with rounded punctures in both sexes. Antennal club length 1.7–2.0 mm. Pronotum anterior angle obtuse and sharp, posterior angle acute and lobed. Metaventral process length 1.7–2.2 mm . Posterior metatibial with 14–20 spicules. Elytra with 3–5 longitudinal rows of sparsely-spaced, large, circular to ovoid, white to yellowish-white scales ( Figs. 36–37 ).

Female . Clypeus weakly convex apically, without median cleft; nearly as long as labrum; strongly recurved at approximately 45 0 laterally; strongly indented mesally. Antennal club length 1.3-1.5 mm . Prosternal process length 2.0– 2.6 mm . Posterior metatibial with 25–37 spicules.

38 39 40 Specimens examined .

Leucopholis

42, habitus, dorsal aspect (photograph of a non-type from MLU, courtesy of Dr. Karla Schneider); 43, habitus, dorsal aspect (photograph of a non-type from ZMHB, courtesy of Dr. Joachim Willers).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks . Externally similar to
L. irrorata .
Phallobase of male genitalia is distinctly longer than parameres. The species is well represented in the northern part of the Philippines especially in Central Luzon and least represented in the southern part particularly in the Mindanao region. It is least represented in the eastern coasts wherein majority of the specimens collected in the Samar and Leyte areas are
L. irrorata
. Distribution was also based on several museum collections deposited locally and internationally from 1911–2010 ( Fig. 41 ). The specimens examined match the digital photographs of Ernst Brenske specimens ( Fig. 42 ) from the ZMHB (provided by Dr. Joachim Willers) and Burmeister’s syntypes ( Fig. 43 ) from the MLU (provided by Dr. Karla Schneider).
